column5: message

Merge pull request #247 from JohnSundell/deprecation

Deprecate Unbox

Deprecate Unbox

This change marks Unbox as deprecated, in favor of Swift’s built-in
`Codable` API and the Codextended project. Unbox will be kept online
for as long as possible (although soon it will be made read-only using
GitHub’s archive feature).

Added to this change is a migration guide which aims to make it easier
for developers using Unbox to start migrating to `Codable`.
Bump Podspec to 4.0.0
README: Update for now optional unboxing API

Merge pull request #245 from JohnSundell/swift5

Update project for Xcode 10.2 and Swift 5

Update project for Xcode 10.2 and Swift 5

This change updates Unbox to be fully compatible with Xcode 10.2 and
Swift 5. Since Swift now supports automatic flattening of optionals
generated using `try?`, Unbox now uses throwing methods for all of
its `unbox` methods. While this requires the API user to prefix a call
to unbox an optional with `try?`, it avoids type inference issues since
now `try?`-prefixed calls can be mixed up with calls returning optionals.

underlying implementation to make Unbox successfully build & test for Swift

Merge pull request #134 from JohnSundell/2.2.0

Unbox 2.2.0
Move private UnboxError extension to private extensions section

Use nodes for key path unboxing instead of enum with associated values

Speeds up key path unboxing with ~50%.
Streamline collection unboxing by using element transformers

Optimize accessing a value by a key only

Don’t go through same code path as for key paths, since this requires an
iteration.
Throw directly if array has an invalid element type
Remove redundant extension making String conform to UnboxableKey

Simplify & make error output more readable

Unbox will now throw only a single error type, with a detailed description
or what went wrong. This makes it a lot easier to consume, as you no longer
have to pattern match against multiple error cases, and instead can use
`UnboxError` as a single type.

Unbox errors are now also a lot more readable and provides a lot more debug
information. For example, an invalid array element would previously just return
an “invalid value” error, while now it outputs the following:

“[UnboxError] An error occurred while unboxing path “key.path”: Invalid array
element (InvalidValue) at index 5”.
Bump Podspec to 2.1.1

README: Add contact badge & links to Travis + CocoaPods

Add full support for 64 bit Int/UInt on 32 bit platforms

This change uses the same technique as in Wrap to support Int64 & UInt64
number types on 32 bit platforms, by using an NSNumber wrapper.

This change also adds support for explicit UInt32/64 values.

Unboxer: Make initializers public

Now that Unboxer is stateless, we can enable the API user to construct
instances of it. Before, there was a risk that state would be shared
if Unboxer wasn’t initialized within the framework, but that’s no longer
the case.

This way of creating Unboxers is now an alternative to using the custom
unboxing API.

Merge pull request #126 from JohnSundell/2.0

Unbox 2.0
README: “contains” -> “supports”
Update README for 2.0 APIs
Migrate top-level APIs to using key/keyPath convention + update docs

Rename UnboxableWithContext.ContextType -> UnboxContextType

Use namespacing to avoid type alias collisions
Reorder UnboxTransform & use it everywhere

Rename top level Unbox functions to unbox

To follow the Swift 3 API conventions.
Unify implementations by using Optional.map() & orThrow()
Unify default & custom Unboxing APIs

Remove UnboxValueResolver

All unboxing is now done by Unboxer itself.
Remove old UnboxValueResolver code
Reorder all unbox() overloads based on access model + required/optional
Add explicit self reference where missing

Migrate overloads producing UnboxFormatter types to new API

This also enables the removal of UnboxableWithFormatter, while retaining
the same functionality by using UnboxableFormatter directly.
Migrate overloads producing collections of UnboxableWithContext to new API
Migrate overloads that produces UnboxableWithContext to new key/keyPath API
Migrate overload that produces Unboxable to new key/keyPath API

Make Dictionary an Unbox compatible type

This enables us to remove all dictionary-based unbox() overloads.
Also add UnboxErrors for invalid dictionary key/value types.

Merge most array-based unbox() overloads into one

This change merges most unbox() overloads that return array types into
a single one. This is done by making Array an `UnboxCompatibleType`.

Drop support for unbox(key:index) method

This method has been made obsolete by the introduction of key path support.
So `unbox(key: “key”, index: 0)` becomes `unbox(keyPath: “key.0”)`.

Introduce new value resolving implementation and key/keyPath API

To make Unbox’s API more “Swift 3 native”, there will now be different
methods depending on if you’re unboxing by key or key path. To make this
possible without having to duplicate a lot of code, a smarter value resolving
implementation is introduced.

This change affects standard types + arrays of standard types.

All types will in subsequent commits be migrated to the new code.

Drop support for context parameter for Unboxable types

The option to pass a context when beginning the unboxing process has only
been kept around for backwards compatibility (that we can now break! ^^),
since the `UnboxableWithContext` type is a more type-safe way to achieve
the same result.

Use same unbox() implementation for Raw, enum & transformable types

Also add test case covering the unboxing of [UnboxableEnum].

Start streamlining implementation by delegating Unboxing to the types themselves

This change introduces an `unbox()` function on `UnboxCompatibleType` and starts
moving unboxing logic into the types themselves, rather than relying on a central
implementation in `UnboxValueResolver`.

Unboxer: Remove hasFailed + failureInfo

No longer needed

Merge UnboxError/UnboxValueError + remove failing APIs

This change merges the `UnboxError` and `UnboxValueError` types into one,
since now only one value may be thrown from an `unbox()` function call.

Since Swift’s built-in `do, try, catch` error handling model is now used
throughout Unbox, the APIs previously used to fail an Unboxer may now be
removed.

This change also migrates the error enum to using a lower cased initial
letter, to conform to the Swift 3 API naming guidelines.

Remove unboxFallbackValue()

This function used to make sure that a value was always returned, since
Unbox used to keep track of failure states internally, instead of using
Swift’s built in error handling with do, try, catch (Unbox was originally
written in Swift 1).

However, now that Unbox uses modern error handling, there’s no need for
this function, so it has been removed.

Enable init(unboxer:) + init(unboxer:context:) to throw

This change changes the initializer signature for `Unboxable` and
`UnboxableWithContext` to `throw`. This enables a more quick exit out
of initializers whenever an invalid value was found, making Unbox faster.
This is accomplished by using try when unboxing a required value.

It also has the added benefit of enabling API users to manually exit out
of an initializer by throwing, instead of having to use the failing APIs
on `Unboxer`.

The only downside of this approach is that the error reporting goes back
to only returning a single error (as we’ll exit early, instead of gathering
all errors), however, for the sake of API streamlining + performance, this
is a tradeoff that is worth making.

By introducing more explicit generic parameters we can get it to work.

Bump Podspec to 1.7

Change isKeyPath parameter’s default value to true

It’s more likely that dots are being used as key paths, than keys containing
dots. While we still want to support keys that include dots, we’re now using
`true` as the default value for the `isKeyPath` parameter, so that the default
matches the most common use case.

Add support for converting Ints -> Bool, UInt, Int32, Int64, Double, Float

This change makes any unboxed Integer implicitly convertible to a series
of numeric types, and introduces support for explicitly telling Unbox
that a 32 or 64 bit integer should be unboxed.
Bump Podspec to 1.6
Improve error messages for invalid values

Don’t require an UnboxableByTransform’s raw value to conform to UnboxRawType

This enables collections (like arrays) to act like raw values

Improve Array + Dictionary type safety

Arrays & Dictionaries can now only be unboxed if they:
A) Are explicitly typed as [AnyObject] or [String : AnyObject]
B) Contain only raw values (like Int, String, etc)
C) Contain nested collections

This will improve the type safety of Unbox, since the following is no
longer possible (and will cause a compile time error):

let customTypes: [CustomType] = unboxer.unbox(“customTypes”)

Modernize protocol APIs

transformUnboxedString() -> transform(unboxedString:)
transformUnboxedValue() -> transform(unboxedValue:)
transformUnboxedKey() -> transform(unboxedKey:)
formatUnboxedValue() -> format(unboxedValue:)

Automatically convert strings into numbers

This change makes it so that if a number is being unboxed, but a string
was found, an attempt will be made to transform the string into a number
of the given type. That way, no manual transformation code needs to be
written, and the same simple unbox() API can be used.

Merge pull request #51 from JohnSundell/nested-collections

Support nested collections of any type

Support nested collections of any type

This change makes Unbox support nested collections (arrays & dictionaries)
of any type, rather than being constrained to raw values and transformed
types. While this theoretically enables decoding code to be written using
invalid JSON types - the extra level of flexibility is worth it.

Merge pull request #50 from JohnSundell/allow-invalid-array-elements

Skip invalid data instead of exiting completely v3
UnboxError: Use base description for all error cases
Update README after merged Unbox() and UnboxOrThrow() functions
Update documentation for allowInvalidElements

Enable nested arrays of dictionaries to have invalid elements

Same change as the previous commit, but for nested array of dictionaries;
an `allowInvalidElements` parameter has now been added to enable the API
user to control whether nil should be returned or not if an invalid element
was encountered.

Enable top-level arrays of dictionaries to have invalid elements

This change adds a parameter to all Unbox() functions that produce an
array of models - `allowInvalidElements` - which when set to `true`
enables a partial array to be returned in case an invalid element was
encountered.

Merge Unbox() and UnboxOrThrow()

The Unbox() function was introduced before Swift 2 and the do/try/catch
model, so the UnboxOrThrow() was an easy way to ease in that pattern without
breaking existing usage. However, since the same behavior as the current
version of Unbox() has (it returns nil on failure) can be achieved with
try? UnboxOrThrow() there’s no need to keep maintaining two separate
functions. So, with this change, UnboxOrThrow() is renamed to Unbox() and
the old Unbox() function is removed.
